matter.summary: Patricia Williams, 52, underwent routine gallbladder surgery at Metropolitan Hospital on March 12, 2024. Surgeon Dr. Richard Hayes negligently severed her common bile duct, requiring emergency corrective surgery and causing permanent liver damage and ongoing complications.

documents.title: Operative Report - Initial Surgery
documents.summary: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed by Dr. Hayes. Report notes 'difficult anatomy' but does not mention bile duct injury. Patient experienced severe pain and jaundice post-op.
facts: Surgery duration was 3.5 hours (typical duration: 45-90 minutes)
No intraoperative cholangiogram performed despite difficult anatomy
Patient's bilirubin levels rose dramatically within 24 hours

documents.title: Emergency Department Records
documents.summary: Patient returned to ED with severe abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. CT scan revealed bile leak and fluid collection. Emergency surgery scheduled.
facts: Bilirubin level: 8.5 mg/dL (normal: 0.1-1.2)
Clear signs of bile peritonitis
Delay in recognition of bile duct injury

documents.title: Corrective Surgery Report
documents.summary: Hepatobiliary surgeon Dr. Chen performed emergency hepaticojejunostomy to repair severed common bile duct. Report confirms complete transection of duct.
facts: Common bile duct was completely severed 2cm from bifurcation
Significant bile peritonitis requiring extensive washout
Patient required ICU admission for 5 days

documents.title: Expert Review - Dr. Sarah Mitchell, M.D.
documents.summary: Board-certified general surgeon reviewed records. Opines that Dr. Hayes departed from accepted standards of care by failing to obtain intraoperative cholangiogram and failing to properly identify critical structures.
facts: Standard of care requires cholangiogram when anatomy is unclear
Bile duct injury is a known complication but departure from standard of care caused injury
Earlier recognition of injury would have reduced complications

documents.title: Gastroenterology Follow-up
documents.summary: Dr. Patel documents ongoing liver dysfunction, chronic cholangitis, and need for lifelong monitoring. Patient cannot return to work as elementary school teacher.
facts: Permanent liver damage with elevated enzymes
Recurrent infections requiring hospitalizations
Unable to work due to fatigue and frequent medical needs

events.description: Initial gallbladder surgery with bile duct injury
Attempted return to work; unable to complete day

facts: Failure to perform intraoperative cholangiogram
Failure to properly identify anatomical structures
Failure to recognize injury intraoperatively
Surgery performed at hospital facility
Dr. Hayes was hospital employee or apparent agent
Hospital credentialed and supervised surgeon

authorities.summary: 2.5 year statute of limitations for medical malpractice
Pattern jury instruction for medical malpractice
Standard of care for physicians in New York
Certificate of merit requirement - satisfied with Dr. Mitchell's affidavit

strengths: Clear deviation from standard of care per expert
Well-documented injury with objective medical evidence
Permanent disability preventing return to work
Strong expert witness with impeccable credentials
weaknesses: Bile duct injury is a known risk of surgery (informed consent defense possible)
Defense may argue injury was unavoidable complication
concessions: Willing to dismiss individual doctor if hospital accepts full liability
Open to structured settlement for future medical care
evidentiary_gaps: Need life care plan and economic analysis
Need to depose Dr. Hayes and surgical team
